questions.text: In a patient of filaria, Max density of mf in blood is reported between:

options.label: D

A 40-year-old woman with a history of smoking is followed for 10 years to assess development of lung cancer. What type of study is this?
A cohort study finds RR = 4.2. What does this indicate?

options.label: B
options.text: Exposed are 4.2 times more likely to develop disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Exposed are 4.2 times more likely to develop disease

questions.text: Promotion of physical activity in schools to prevent obesity falls under:
Which of the following is NOT one of the Bradford Hill criteria for causation?
In chronic diseases like diabetes, what will be the trend if incidence stays same but survival improves?
In a left-skewed distribution, which measure is highest?
Which test is used to compare the means of two independent groups?
A study shows p = 0.04. What does this mean?

options.label: D
options.text: High risk of Type II error

questions.correct_answer: C. 4% chance results due to chance

questions.text: Rejecting a true null hypothesis is:
In a test with 95% specificity, what is the chance of a false positive?
A 45-year-old patient with severe depression loses 5 healthy years due to illness. What does this contribute to?
An outbreak has a sudden peak and then decline in cases. What type of epidemic is this?
A child eats contaminated food and develops diarrhea in 12 hours. What term defines this interval?
A health worker visits households weekly to check for new TB cases. This is:
During a routine inspection of a PHC, vaccines are found stored at-5°C. Which vaccine is most likely to lose potency at this temperature?
A health worker notices that the inner square of a Vaccine Vial Monitor has turned darker than the outer circle. What should be done with the vaccine?

options.label: D
options.text: Store it back in the refrigerator

questions.text: A child develops a high fever and seizures within 24 hours after receiving the DPT vaccine. This is classified as:

Mock drills in disaster management are done to:
Most important public health activity post-disaster is:

Triage in disaster management is used to:
questions.correct_answer: C. Prioritize patients based on severity

questions.text: The concept of ergonomics relates to:
questions.correct_answer: C. Fit between worker and job

questions.text: All are live vaccines except:

One ASHA is appointed for every:

If sample size increases, what happens to standard error?
A health team conducts a survey to estimate the prevalence of anemia in pregnant women. What type of study is this?
You compare mean cholesterol levels among 4 dietary groups. Which test is most appropriate?
A test for Hepatitis B has a specificity of 98%. What does this mean?

options.label: A
options.text: 98% of patients with disease test positive

options.label: D
options.text: It has low false negative rate

questions.correct_answer: B. 98% of healthy individuals test negative

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Hill’s criteria for causation?
A new antihypertensive drug is tested in 200 patients randomly assigned to drug or placebo. Which element makes this an RCT?
In a village, most people earn ₹5000/month, but a few wealthy residents earn ₹1,00,000. Which measure of central tendency is most affected?
A researcher concludes that Drug A is better than Drug B, but in reality, there is no difference. What type of error is this?
A cohort study on smoking and lung cancer followed 1000 smokers and 1000 non-smokers for 10 years. 150 smokers and 30 non-smokers developed lung cancer. Calculate the relative risk.

A study measured the haemoglobin levels of 1000 women in a population. The mean was 12 g/dL with a standard deviation of 1.5 g/dL. Approximately how many women are expected to have haemoglobin between 9 and 15 g/dL?
A researcher measures haemoglobin levels in 100 adults. The mean is 13.5 g/dL and standard deviation is 1.5. What does the standard deviation represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The range of haemoglobin in the population

options.label: B
options.text: The average of the data points

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of data around the mean

questions.correct_answer: C. The spread of data around the mean

questions.text: A 35-year-old female ASHA worker is conducting a session on exclusive breastfeeding in a village. Despite repeated efforts, the mothers continue giving water to newborns. What is the most likely barrier to effective communication in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Psychological barrier due to resistance to change

options.label: B
options.text: Semantic barrier due to technical language

questions.correct_answer: B. Semantic barrier due to technical language

questions.text: A Primary Health Centre organizes a session for diabetic patients using local language, flip charts, and interactive Q&A. The goal is to enable lifestyle change through understanding. Which of the following best defines this activity?

A district hospital invites experts to discuss the rising cases of dengue. A moderator leads the discussion and there is live interaction between experts but no audience Q&A. What technique is being used?
A program planner compares the cost of setting up a free cataract surgery camp vs. the monetary value of increased productivity in treated patients. This is an example of:

Which cancer is most commonly seen among woodworkers exposed to wood dust?

According to the Factories Act, what is the maximum permissible working hours per week for an adult worker?
Under the Factories Act, the role of a Welfare Officer becomes mandatory in factories employing:
A 25-year-old male from a forest area presents with fever, myalgia, and a black necrotic eschar on the thigh. Which vector is most likely involved?
In a village with stagnant water and high mosquito density, a child develops fever with lymphadenopathy and chyluria. What is the correct vector identification method for the disease?

In a health awareness campaign, a noisy market and uninterested crowd result in poor message retention. Which is the barrier?

A team wants to understand why adolescent girls are avoiding iron tablets. They select 8 girls of the same age and socio-economic status and conduct a guided discussion. Which is the primary advantage of this method over a questionnaire?

options.label: C
options.text: In-depth exploration of attitudes and beliefs

questions.correct_answer: C. In-depth exploration of attitudes and beliefs
